questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with stage IV pelvic organ prolapse has severe comorbidities that make her a high-risk candidate for extensive surgery. She is not sexually active and desires minimal intervention. What is the most appropriate surgical approach?
questions.solution:
LeFort partial colpocleisis: A minimally invasive option for severe prolapse in non-sexually active patients with high surgical risk.

OPTION a) Sacrocolpopexy: Involves more extensive surgery not suitable for high-risk patients.

OPTION b) Total pelvic floor reconstruction: Complex and high-risk; not recommended for her condition.

OPTION c) Vaginal hysterectomy: While less invasive than some other procedures, it still involves removing the uterus, which may be more surgery than necessary for a non-sexually active patient seeking minimal intervention.

OPTION d) LeFort partial colpocleisis: A minimally invasive option for severe prolapse in non-sexually active patients with high surgical risk.

KEY TAKE AWAY - In pt of pelvic organ prolapse with high comorbidities and who are not sexually active and no fertility preservation required, minimally invasive surgeries suited best i.e lefort colpocleisis. REST ALL PROCEDURES REQUIRE EXTENSIVE SURGERY.

questions.text: A 32 year old nulliparous female with 3rd degree uterine prolapse, with no cystocoele & rectocoele, wishes to preserve fertility. What is the best treatment option out of the following?
questions.solution:
Abdominal sling: This procedure, also known as sacrohysteropexy, involves using a mesh or sling to support the uterus via the abdominal route. It is suitable for young women who wish to preserve fertility because it corrects the prolapse while maintaining the uterus and reproductive potential. It avoids the removal of the uterus and supports the pelvic organs effectively.

OPTION b) Ward-Mayo hysterectomy: This procedure involves vaginal hysterectomy +pelvic floor repair and is not appropriate for women who wish to preserve fertility, as it results in the loss of reproductive capability.

OPTION c) Le Fort's colpocleisis: This operation involves partial closure of the vagina and is not suitable for women wishing to maintain fertility, as it prevents vaginal intercourse and future pregnancy.

OPTION d) Baldy Webster operation: This operation, also known as uterine suspension or plication of the uterosacral ligaments, is less commonly performed and may not provide as reliable long-term support for the uterus compared to an abdominal sling. It is primarily used in older women who are not focused on fertility preservation. The best treatment option for preserving fertility while effectively managing the 3rd-degree uterine prolapse in this young, nulliparous patient.

Key Take away - Abdominal sling is best suited for young nulliparous women who wish to preserve fertility. Rest all are not suited for preserving fertility.

questions.text: Identify the type of pessary:
questions.solution: Key Take Away - Pessary uses-pelvic organ prolapse (can be used in pregnant women and elderly female with prolapse), urinary incontinence, delivering medication to treat vaginal infections.

questions.text: Most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in India is:
questions.solution:
Obstructed labour is the most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in India. Prolonged pressure of the fetal head against the bladder during obstructed labour can lead to ischemic necrosis and subsequent formation of a fistula between the bladder and the vagina. This is particularly prevalent in low-resource settings where access to timely obstetric care is limited.

Vesicovaginal fistula:

OPTION A: Wertheim's hysterectomy

This is a radical hysterectomy often performed for cervical cancer, which can occasionally lead to vesicovaginal fistula as a complication. However, it is not the most common cause in India.

OPTION B: Cervical Cancer

Cervical cancer can cause a vesicovaginal fistula due to direct invasion of the tumor or radiation therapy used in its treatment. Although a possible cause, it is not the most prevalent reason in India.

OPTION C: Vesical Cancer

Cancer of the bladder can lead to the formation of fistulas with adjacent organs, including the vagina. However, this is a relatively rare cause compared to others.

Take away - In countries like India Mc cause of vvf is obstructed labour while in high resource setting countries iatrogenic causes (related to surgeries) are common

choices.text: Three swab test with urine detection

questions.text: In the case of a suspected vesicovaginal fistula, which of the following is the most accurate method for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cystoscopy is the most accurate method for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula as it allows direct visualization of the bladder and can confirm the presence of a fistulous tract.

OPTION A: Ultrasound of the pelvis can provide some information about pelvic anatomy and may help detect fluid collections or masses but is less specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistulas.

OPTION B: Three swab test with urine detection is a diagnostic test used to identify a fistula by checking the presence of urine in the vaginal discharge.

While useful in the initial diagnosis, it is less definitive compared to cystoscopy.

OPTION C: Cystoscopy is the most accurate method for diagnosing a vesicovaginal fistula. It involves inserting a thin, flexible tube with a camera (cystoscope) into the bladder through the urethra to directly visualize the internal structures of the bladder and identify the presence of any abnormal openings or fistulas.

OPTION D: Vaginal biopsy is used to diagnose conditions affecting vaginal tissue but is not used to confirm vesicovaginal fistulas.

Key Take Away - Cystoscopy is the most definitive test to directly visualize and confirm the presence of a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: A 34 year old multipara previous 3 LSCS with last Caesarean 7 months ago, presents with cyclical haematuria. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vesicouterine fistula is a type of fistula that forms between the bladder and the uterus. It is commonly associated with previous cesarean sections, especially when there is scarring or surgical trauma.

Cyclical hematuria, which is the presence of blood in the urine that corresponds with the menstrual cycle, is a characteristic symptom of a vesicouterine fistula due to the interaction between the menstrual and urinary systems through the abnormal connection.

OPTION A: Ureterovaginal fistula involves a fistula between the ureter and the vagina, typically presenting with continuous urinary leakage rather than cyclical hematuria.

OPTION B: Vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the bladder and the vagina, resulting in continuous urinary leakage into the vagina. It does not typically cause cyclical hematuria.

OPTION D: Bladder endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the bladder, which can cause hematuria, but it is less likely to be cyclical. It is often associated with other symptoms such as pelvic pain, especially related to menstruation.

Key Take Away - After LSCS Mc fistula in vesicouterine. It commonly presents with cyclical hematuria.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a sensation of heaviness and bulging in the vaginal area. She also complains of difficulty with urination and occasional constipation. On examination, a significant uterine prolapse is noted, with the cervix protruding beyond the vaginal introitus. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Pessary insertion: A nonsurgical option, often used as first-line treatment for patients with significant prolapse, especially those who are elderly or not suitable for surgery.

OPTION A: Pelvic floor exercises: Suitable for mild prolapse or as a preventive measure, but less effective for significant prolapse.

OPTION C: Total abdominal hysterectomy: A surgical option but is more invasive and usually considered if other measures fail or if there are other indications for hysterectomy.

OPTION D: Uterosacral ligament suspension: A surgical procedure to support the prolapsed uterus but not the first-line management for initial treatment.

Key Take Away - Pessary preferred in women who are elderly and not suitable for surgery. Non surgical management used first over surgical.

questions.text: Which ligament primarily supports the bladder and anterior vaginal wall, preventing cystocele?
questions.solution:
The pubocervical ligament, part of the anterior compartment support, helps maintain the position of the bladder and anterior vaginal wall, reducing the risk of anterior compartment prolapse (cystocele).

OPTION a) Pubocervical ligament: The pubocervical ligament, also known as the pubovesical fascia, is a key support structure for the bladder and anterior vaginal wall. It connects the bladder to the pubic bone, providing crucial support and preventing the descent of these structures, thereby helping to prevent cystocele.

OPTION b) Cardinal ligament: The cardinal ligament (also called the transverse cervical ligament) primarily supports the uterus and cervix, attaching them to the pelvic sidewalls. While it provides some support to the upper vagina, it is not directly involved in supporting the bladder or preventing cystocele.

OPTION c) Round ligament: The round ligament extends from the uterus through the inguinal canal to the labia majora. It primarily helps maintain the anteverted position of the uterus and does not contribute significantly to the support of the bladder or anterior vaginal wall.

OPTION d) Broad ligament: The broad ligament is a peritoneal fold that supports the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. It provides minimal structural support to the pelvic organs and does not directly support the bladder or anterior vaginal wall, hence it plays no significant role in preventing cystocele.

Key Take Away - Pubocervical ligament connecting bladder to cervix prevents descent of these organ hence preventing cystocele

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sensation of heaviness and a bulging mass in her vagina. She has three children, all delivered vaginally. She has a BMI of 32 and a history of chronic cough due to smoking. What is the most significant risk factor contributing to her prolapse?
questions.solution:
Multiparity with vaginal deliveries is the most significant risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse because the pelvic floor muscles and ligaments can be weakened by the repetitive trauma of childbirth.

OPTION a) High BMI:

  • Obesity is a known risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse due to increased intra-abdominal pressure, which can weaken the pelvic floor muscles over time. However, it is not the most significant risk factor compared to multiparity and vaginal deliveries.

OPTION b) Chronic cough:

  • Chronic cough from smoking increases intra-abdominal pressure, which can exacerbate prolapse. However, it is less impactful compared to the direct trauma and stretching of the pelvic support structures caused by multiple vaginal deliveries.

OPTION c) Multiparity with vaginal deliveries:

  • This is the most significant risk factor. Multiple vaginal deliveries can cause direct trauma and stretching to the pelvic floor muscles and ligaments, leading to weakening and eventual prolapsem. The mechanical strain during delivery significantly impacts pelvic support structures, making this the primary risk factor.

OPTION d) Smoking:

  • Smoking can contribute to pelvic organ prolapse indirectly by causing chronic cough and weakening connective tissue. However, the impact of smoking alone is less significant than the physical impact of multiple vaginal deliveries.

Key Take Away: Multiparous women with vaginal delivery is the most important risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of third-degree uterine prolapse. She is sexually active and wishes to retain her uterus and avoid hysterectomy. On examination, there is significant uterine descent with no associated cystocele or rectocele. After discussing surgical options with her, she opts for a procedure that suspends the uterus without removing it. The surgeon decides to perform a Purandare sling operation. Which ligament will be utilized in the Purandare sling operation for suspending the uterus in this patient?
questions.solution:
The Purandare sling operation involves the use of the round ligament to suspend the uterus. The round ligament is sutured and slung around the uterus to elevate and support it, making this approach suitable for younger women desiring to maintain reproductive function.

OPTION b) Cardinal ligament: The cardinal ligaments provide lateral support to the uterus but are not used in the Purandare sling operation.

OPTION c) Uterosacral ligament: Uterosacral ligaments provide posterior support and are used in other prolapse surgeries like uterosacral colpopexy but not in Purandare sling.

OPTION d) Broad ligament: The broad ligament supports the uterus in a broad sense but is not directly used in the Purandare sling procedure.

Key Take Away - Round ligament whose main function is maintaing the uterus in anteverted position is used in Purandare repair which is done in young women desiring fertility prevention.

questions.text: All of the following are mandatory to be documented prior to first prescription of Combined Hormonal Contraception (CHC), except?
questions.solution:
Pelvic examination is not required prior to initiation of CHC

A recent, accurate blood pressure recording should be documented for all women prior to first CHC prescription (OPTION A)

BMI should be documented for all women prior to CHC prescription (OPTION B)

Assessment of medical eligibility for CHC should include medical conditions, lifestyle factors and family medical history (OPTION D)

A drug history should be identified: any prescribed or non-prescribed drug that could affect the effectiveness of the contraceptive and vice versa

KEY TAKEAWAY: Breast examination, cervical screening, testing for thrombophilia, hyperlipidemia or diabetes mellitus and liver function tests are not routinely required prior to initiation of CHC.

Remember it as the following mnemonic

"My Provider Helps Ladies In Contraceptive Choices"

  • Medical History
  • Physical Examination
  • History of Reproductive and Sexual Health
  • Lab Tests
  • Informed Consent
  • Counselling and Education
  • Contraindications Check

Reference: FSRH guidelines on Combined Hormonal Contraception

questions.text: A 32-year old woman is on combined hormonal contraception. She is scheduled for an orthopedic surgery in near future. She should switch to an alternative contraceptive method at least how many weeks prior to planned major surgery or expected period of limited mobility?
questions.solution:
• With regard to the use of CHC (Combined hormonal contraception) by women undergoing surgery, it is advised that "estrogen-containing contraceptives should preferably be discontinued (and adequate alternative contraceptive arrangements made) 4 weeks before major elective surgery and all surgery to the legs or surgery which involves prolonged immobilisation of a lower limb.
  • This precaution is taken because CHCs can increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), particularly in situations where immobility is a factor. Switching to a non-estrogen-containing contraceptive method can help reduce this risk.
  • They should normally be recommenced at the first menses occurring at least 2 weeks after full mobilisation.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

If combined hormonal contraception (CHC) is not stopped before surgery, especially if there is a risk of immobility, the potential risks include:

  1. Increased Risk of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE):
    • CHC can increase the risk of blood clots, and surgery or prolonged immobility can further elevate this risk.
  2. Complications from Clots:
    • Potential complications from VTE include deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and other thrombotic events, which can be serious and require urgent medical attention.

Reference: FSRH guidelines on Combined Hormonal Contraception

questions.text: Primary mode of action of desogestrel-containing Progesterone only pill (POP)?
questions.solution:
The primary mode of action of desogestrel-containing pill is inhibition of ovulation (OPTION A)

Progestogen-only pills (POPs) other than desogestrel work through three mechanisms:

  1. Thickening of Cervical Mucus (OPTION B):
    • POPs make the cervical mucus thicker and more viscous, creating a barrier that makes it difficult for sperm to penetrate and reach the egg.
  2. Endometrial Alteration/Asynchrony (OPTION C):
    • POPs can alter the endometrium (the lining of the uterus), making it less suitable for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  3. Slowing of tubal motility (OPTION D):
    • By slowing the movement of the fallopian tubes, the minipill (POP) reduces the likelihood of an egg meeting sperm.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  1. Inhibits LH Surge:
    • Desogestrel prevents the release of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).
    • LH is necessary for the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation).
  2. Prevents Ovulation:
    • Without the LH surge, the egg remains in the ovary.
    • Primary Action of desogestrel.
  3. Thickens Cervical Mucus:
    • Desogestrel makes cervical mucus thicker and more sticky.
    • This creates a barrier that is difficult for sperm to penetrate.
  4. Alters Endometrium:
    • The lining of the uterus (endometrium) becomes less suitable for a fertilized egg to implant.
    • This reduces the chances of pregnancy, even if fertilization occurs.

Overall, desogestrel works by preventing ovulation and creating a hostile environment for sperm and a fertilized egg.

Reference: FSRH guidelines on Combined Hormonal Contraception

choices.text: It contains estradiol valerate instead of ethinyl estradiol
It is an estrogen step-down & progestin step-up regime
Can be freely used in women with history of thromboembolic events

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about "Qlaira", the new generation oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
• Qlaira is a quadriphasic contraceptive which uses estradiol valerate (OPTION A) and dienogest (OPTION B)
  • It is a novel combined oral contraceptive (COC) for continuous administration, with a complex quadriphasic dose regimen
  • It is an estrogen step-down & progestin step-up regime (OPTION C)

Estrogen Step-Down

  • Initial Higher Dose: The regimen starts with a higher dose of estrogen in the early part of the cycle. This provides a robust hormonal environment similar to the natural menstrual cycle's early phase.
  • Gradual Reduction: Over the course of the cycle, the estrogen dose gradually decreases. This step-down approach mimics the natural decline in estrogen levels that occurs later in the menstrual cycle.

Progestin Step-Up

  • Initial Lower Dose: At the start of the cycle, the progestin component (dienogest) is administered in lower doses.
  • Gradual Increase: As the cycle progresses, the dose of progestin is increased. This step-up approach is designed to enhance the endometrial lining's protection against pregnancy and to support the hormonal balance as the cycle advances.

Qlaira is designed to closely mimic the natural hormonal changes that occur during a menstrual cycle, using a step-down approach for estrogen and a step-up approach for progestin. This unique formulation helps to manage hormone levels in a way that closely resembles the body's natural fluctuations, potentially leading to a more natural and balanced menstrual cycle experience.

  • It is contraindicated in women with prior history of a thromboembolic phenomenon (Hence OPTION D is the incorrect statement)

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Qlaira is a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC) that, like other CHCs, is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).

questions.text: A couple seeks counselling regarding emergency contraception after an unprotected sexual intercourse. Which of the following is most effective method of emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
EMERGENCY CONTRACEPTION

Definition:

  • Involves using drugs or a device to prevent pregnancy.
  • Known as "postcoital contraception" or the "morning-after pill".

Indications for EC:

  1. Recent unprotected intercourse
  2. Possible failure of another contraceptive method (e.g., condom breakage)

EC Options:

  1. Copper IUD (OPTION A)
    • Most Effective Method: The most effective method of emergency contraception.
    • Insertion: Must be inserted within 5-7 days of unprotected intercourse.
    • Office Visit: Requires a visit to the healthcare provider for placement.
  2. Ulipristal Acetate (OPTION B)
    • Mechanism: A progestin receptor modulator that delays ovulation.
    • Timing: Must be taken within 120 hours (5 days) after intercourse.
    • Effectiveness: Remains highly effective within this time frame.
  3. Levonorgestrel (OPTION C)
    • Timing: Recommended to be taken within 72 hours after intercourse, but still effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after.
    • Effectiveness: Efficacy decreases after 72 hours.
    • Availability: Available over-the-counter.
  4. Mifepristone (OPTION D) is primarily used for medical abortion rather than emergency contraception (EC). However, it can sometimes be used off-label for EC in specific circumstances.

Mechanism:

  • Action: Mifepristone is a progestin receptor antagonist. It works by blocking progesterone, which is necessary for maintaining the endometrial lining. This can prevent implantation if used early in the menstrual cycle.

Timing and Administration:

  • Timing: If used for EC, it is most effective when taken within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse, similar to ulipristal acetate.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

EC pills are intended for emergency use only and should not be used as a regular form of contraception. Regular contraceptive methods are more effective for ongoing prevention.

choices.text: Previous C-section is a contraindication for CuT insertion
Antibiotic prophylaxis is mandatory before intrauterine device insertion
The most common adverse effect of the copper IUD is increased menstrual bleeding & cramping
Current PID is an absolute contraindication to CuT insertion

questions.text: A 34 year old P2L2 woman with previous Caesarean section wishes for a Copper IUD insertion. She is on D5 of her menstrual cycle. Her cycles are regular with normal flow & mild dysmenorrhea. Per speculum examination shows a healthy cervix, on bimanual examination, uterus anteverted, normal size, bilateral fornices free. Choose the correct statement out of the following:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Copper IUD (CuT) can generally be inserted in women who have had a previous cesarean section. There is no contraindication based solely on a history of cesarean delivery. In fact, many women who have had cesarean sections choose IUDs as a long-term, reversible contraceptive option.

Considerations:

  • Timing: Postpartum IUD insertion can be done immediately after delivery (within 10 minutes), within the first 48 hours, or delayed until 4-6 weeks postpartum, depending on the healthcare provider's assessment and the patient's condition.
  • Uterine Size and Shape: The healthcare provider will assess the uterus's size and shape, especially in the early postpartum period, to ensure proper placement of the IUD.
  • Risk of Expulsion: Immediate postpartum insertion carries a slightly higher risk of expulsion, but this risk decreases significantly after 4-6 weeks postpartum.

Overall, CuT is a safe and effective option for women with a history of cesarean section.

OPTION B

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely required before the insertion of a copper IUD (CuT). The risk of infection from the insertion procedure itself is low, and studies have shown that routine use of antibiotics before IUD insertion does not significantly reduce the already low risk of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Standard Practice:

  • Screening: It is often recommended to screen for STIs, especially in high-risk populations, and to treat any existing infections before IUD insertion.
  • Aseptic Technique: Using a sterile, aseptic technique (no touch technique)during insertion helps minimize the risk of introducing an infection.

Overall, routine antibiotic prophylaxis is not considered necessary for most patients before CuT insertion.

OPTION C: The most common adverse effect of the copper IUD (CuT) is increased menstrual bleeding and cramping. Many users experience heavier and longer periods, as well as more intense menstrual cramps, especially in the first few months after insertion. These symptoms often diminish over time as the body adjusts to the device.

OPTION D:

Absolute contraindications for the insertion of a copper intrauterine device (CuT) include:

  1. Pregnancy: An IUD should not be inserted if the patient is currently pregnant.
  2. Current Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): Active or recent (within 3 months) PID is a contraindication due to the risk of worsening the infection.
  3. Current Purulent Cervicitis or Active Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI): Insertion should be avoided if there is an active infection like gonorrhea or chlamydia.
  4. Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding: Any undiagnosed abnormal vaginal bleeding should be evaluated before IUD insertion.
  5. Cervical or Uterine Malignancy: Known or suspected cancer of the cervix or uterus is an absolute contraindication.
  6. Distorted Uterine Cavity: Uterine anomalies or fibroids that significantly distort the uterine cavity can make IUD placement difficult or increase the risk of complications.
  7. Copper Allergy or Wilson's Disease: Patients with a known allergy to copper or with Wilson's disease (a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism) should not use a copper IUD.
  8. Recent Postpartum Sepsis: Insertion should be avoided in women with a history of postpartum sepsis until it is safe to proceed.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a combined hormonal contraception method?
questions.solution:
Subdermal progestin-only implant placed under the skin and release progestin over an extended period. Effective for up to 3 years

OPTION A: ORTHO EVRA PATCH

  • Description: A small adhesive patch worn on the skin that releases estrogen and progestin.
  • Usage: Applied once a week for three weeks, followed by a patch-free week.

OPTION B: NUVA Vaginal Ring

  • Description: A flexible ring inserted into the vagina that releases estrogen & progestin hormones.
  • Usage: Worn for three weeks, followed by a ring-free week.

OPTION C: MESIGNYA Contraceptive Injection

  • Description: experimental combined injectable contraceptive that includeS both estrogen and progestin.
  • Usage: Administered by a healthcare provider, usually every month.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Progestin-only contraceptive methods are suitable for individuals who cannot use estrogen-containing methods due to specific health concerns or contraindications. Examples of such conditions or situations include:

1. History of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) or Pulmonary Embolism:

  • Reason: Estrogen-containing contraceptives increase the risk of blood clots, so progestin-only methods are preferred for individuals with a history of clotting disorders.

2. Migraine with Aura:

  • Reason: Estrogen can exacerbate migraines with aura, increasing the risk of stroke. Progestin-only methods are safer for those with this type of migraine.

3. Certain Types of Cancer:

  • Reason: Estrogen-sensitive cancers (e.g., breast cancer) contraindicate the use of estrogen-containing contraceptives. Progestin-only methods are used instead.

4. Severe Hypertension:

  • Reason: High blood pressure can be exacerbated by estrogen. Progestin-only methods are safer for individuals with uncontrolled or severe hypertension.

5. Smoking Over Age 35:

  • Reason: Smokers over 35 years old are at increased risk of cardiovascular events with estrogen-containing contraceptives. Progestin-only methods are recommended for this group.

6. Postpartum Period (Especially Within 3 Weeks):

  • Reason: Estrogen-containing methods are generally avoided in the immediate postpartum period due to increased risk of thrombosis. Progestin-only methods are preferred for breastfeeding women and those recently postpartum.

7. Liver Disease:

  • Reason: Estrogen can be metabolized by the liver, and liver disease can affect its metabolism. Progestin-only methods are used to avoid complications in such cases.

8. Uncontrolled Diabetes with Complications:

  • Reason: Estrogen can affect blood glucose levels and may not be suitable for individuals with diabetes and associated complications. Progestin-only methods are safer for managing these conditions.

Mnemonic to remember the conditions where progestin-only methods are preferred over estrogen-containing methods:

"My Crazy High School Principal Likes Deep Vaults"

  • Migraine with aura
  • Certain types of cancer (e.g., breast cancer)
  • Hypertension (severe or uncontrolled)
  • Smoking over age 35
  • Postpartum period (especially within 3 weeks)
  • Liver disease
  • Diabetes (uncontrolled with complications)
  • Venous thromboembolism history (DVT or PE)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraine with aura seeks contraception. Which method is the most appropriate for her?
questions.solution:
Estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in women with migraine with aura due to the increased risk of stroke.

The most appropriate method for her would be:

Progestin-only contraceptive methods, such as:

  • Progestin-only pills (OPTION B)
  • Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS)
  • Injectable progestin (e.g., Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, DMPA)
  • Progestin-only implant (e.g., etonogestrel implant)

These methods do not carry the same increased risk of stroke as estrogen-containing contraceptives and are considered safe options for women with migraine with aura.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Mnemonic to remember the contraindications for combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) or estrogen containing contraceptives:

"My CUPLETS"

  • M: Migraines with aura
  • C: Cardiovascular disease (including history of stroke, ischemic heart disease, or uncontrolled hypertension)
  • U: Uncontrolled diabetes with vascular complications
  • P: Pregnancy
  • L: Liver disease (severe, such as liver tumors or active hepatitis)
  • E: Estrogen-dependent cancers (e.g., breast cancer)
  • T: Thromboembolic disorders (including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and known thrombophilia)
  • S: Smoking (in women over 35 years old)
